utterances: This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Rebecca Roberts in Washington.
Neal Conan is away.
No matter how you slice it, the economy is still fragile, especially the job market.
American businesses cut another 85,000 jobs in December.
Since the economic downturn began over two years ago, more than seven million jobs have been lost.
During that time, we've checked in periodically with guests and with you, our listeners, to see how you've been doing during the economic tumult.
Kevin Wilk shared a story in December of 2008.
He had just been laid off for the second time in one year.

But what's kind of funny is - or funny, I guess, in a strange way - is that after about a half an hour of getting all the sad looks and I'm so sorry, I know you're going to be fine, things are going to go well, everything happens for a reason, after about an hour, you go, well, I'm sick of that.
I'm going to leave.
We'll check back in with Kevin Wilk in a moment to hear how he's doing today, and we want to hear from you.
Later in the hour, a tribute to Muhammad Ali from the men he fought.
What are the economic indicators in your life that tell you things are getting better or not?
The number here in Washington is 800-989-8255.
Our email address is talk@npr.org, and you can join the conversation at our Web site.
Go to npr.org, and click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Kevin Wilk joins us on the line from Walnut Creek, California.
Welcome back.
Hi, thank you very much.
So we just heard that clip of tape when you talked to Neal Conan.
You had just gotten your second pink slip.
That was 13 months ago.
How are things now?
Well, things certainly are better.
I got a new job towards the end of last year, and that's been going well, with a good, stable company, fingers crossed of course.
But certainly it was an interesting eight, nine months there where, after the second round of layoffs, companies really had tightened up on hiring people and were taking forever to make decisions.
I had a number of interviews, and companies either decided not to hire anybody or to just continue the interview process so long that everything timed out.
So it wasn't like you were sitting home watching daytime TV.
You were actually going out and interviewing, it was just taking a long time?
But the job numbers for December weren't good.
What's happening with housing sales and foreclosures is not good.
So there's a real debate among economists whether we're at a point where we're starting to lift off or whether we're going to remain flat.
Among the biggest names likely considering the race is White House Chief of Staff Rahm Emanuel, who worked on Daley's first successful campaign for mayor in 1989 as a policy advisor and fundraiser.
When asked by Charlie Rose on PBS back in April what other job in government he would like to have, Emanuel said this.
(Soundbite of TV show, ""The Charlie Rose Show"")
First of all, let me say it this way: I hope Mayor Daley seeks re-election.ï¿½I will work and support him if he seeks re-election.
But if Mayor Daley doesn't, one day I would like to run for mayor of the city of Chicago.
In a statement emailed to reporters, Emanuel says Daley's announcement surprised him, but Emanuel refused to say if he might run for mayor in the February 2011 election.
There are many others, though, too many to count, already considering runs for mayor.
Politicians of all stripes in Chicago, from congressmen to aldermen, have been quietly biding their time for years, unwilling to challenge the powerful Daley machine while secretly eying his chair.
Now the day they've been waiting for is finally here.
David Schaper, NPR News, Chicago.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONDSIDERED.
I'm Audie Cornish.
This week, the Federal Reserve acknowledged that the U.S.
economy is losing strength.
Economic recovery has been disappointing, and record-low interest rates have not proven to be as helpful as some predicted.
As it happens, they also mean different things whether you're a borrower or a saver.
Thirty-year-fixed home mortgage rates of 3 and half percent are one thing; earning less than a percent on your savings account is another.
To get a sense of how rock-bottom rates are affecting the country, we decided to reach out to a cross-section of people.
In a moment, we'll hear from a county official, a small- business owner and a personal finance expert.
But first, a homeowner.
Julie Sawitky(ph) and her husband are federal employees who have been prudent about their money.
They max out their 401(k) contributions.
In addition...
We try to save up to 10 percent of our paycheck into a savings account.
However, sometimes it doesn't seem like it's worth it because we earn so little interest.
What interest rates are you getting right now; and what was it like trying to shop around, to find a good interest rate?
Point eight percent is what we're earning now, and we can only get that rate online.
What are your hopes for the future, in terms of savings?
I know that - do you have children, or sort of...
We have four children; one is in college now.
And we have student loans that are going to be coming soon because we don't have enough to cover everything.
So we're saving for that.
We have 529 Plans for all of them.
And the future?
We're just hoping that our property values come up because that is our biggest asset - is our house, and we are underwater at the moment.
And we'd like to refinance to be able to save money - more money.
But that's impossible because banks won't work with us.
So even though there are good interest rates out there, you can't take advantage of it in the case of, say, refinancing.
Not really because when you're underwater, banks don't want to work with you.
We have excellent credit; we have no other debt.
And they just won't take the chance of refinancing us at what we need to refinance at.
What is this like for you, looking at your savings account - which has such a tiny interest rate - and then not being able to refinance again?
I mean, how does it make you feel?
Very frustrated.
You know, they tell you to save money; to save for your retirement and the future, or what have you.
And doing that seems kind of a waste because we can't even keep up with inflation.
So it is a little frustrating.
We feel very stuck.
That's Julie Sawitky of Frederick, Maryland.
Well, we wanted to put Julie's financial story in perspective, so we called Matthew Amster-Burton.
He's a personal finance columnist for Mint.com.
Welcome, Matthew.
Thanks for having me.
So put this in context.
How bad is it for savers like Julie, at the moment?
It's pretty bad.
And .8 really is about the best you're going to do for an online savings account.
I've seen as high as 1 percent, which by historical standards - it's really terrible.
She does have some other options that she can think about.
One of those is I Bonds, which are U.S.
savings bonds, so they're equally safe.
They're backed by the full faith and credit of the U.S.
government.
The great thing about I Bonds is that they guarantee never to pay less than the rate of inflation.
So right now, they're paying 2.2 percent.
And they're not quite the same as a savings account.
But you can buy I Bonds for as little as $25 at a time, and you only have to hang on to them for a year before you can cash them in.
So they're good for medium- to long-term savings.
And that's from the Treasury Department.
What are the other alternatives out there?

So one other alternative is a high-interest checking account, which are sometimes called reward checking accounts, or Kasasa accounts - is a brand name used by community banks and credit unions that offer these.
And this is a checking account that pays a relatively high rate of interest - up to about 2 percent at the moment - but you have to play by their rules.
And what that means is, use your debit card a lot.

So as long as you're willing to use your debit card, say, a dozen times a month, and sign up for direct deposit and e-statements, you can get a much higher rate of interest on your first 10,000, $20,000 or so.
Matthew, essentially, the low interest rates have been billed as something that could help consumers.
But in the end, do you think that it has helped or hurt?
I mean, can people truly take advantage?
Five hundred grams is barely one pound of meat, not nearly enough for one full meal.
Soon a fight breaks out outside between the customers.
Someone has pushed in at the front of the line.
(Soundbite of fighting)
It is then that the owner calls the police.
Unidentified Man #2: If they come through, you're not going to stop them.
There's nothing for them to eat.
They're eating mielie, melon and vegetables, that's all.
They're not getting any protein.
Mr.

Risley, I must say, as a journalist here in Washington, D.C., it's very hard to try to get a real assessment of what's going on in Myanmar, because there's so many mixed messages coming out of that country.
There in Bangkok, is it any clearer there?
Do you have a clearer picture of what's actually going on in-country?
I don't think it's really any clearer or any different, but certainly what is most frustrating today is that this was a natural disaster.
This was a disaster that could have occurred in any country, but it happened in Myanmar.
And in any other country I think by the sixth day afterwards there would be international assistance available and present and ready to help the people who are most in need.

But because of politics, because of history, because of the way people look at different boundaries and borders, there is still a great challenge and a great difficulty in getting something as simple as a biscuit to a man or a woman or a child who've been waiting since Saturday.
We've been speaking with Paul Risley.
He's a spokesperson for the World Food Program.
Mr.
Risley, thank you very much for speaking with us.
Thank you very much.
To become a U.S.
citizen, you first have to live in the U.S.
legally for five years, then pass an interview, a test and a background check.
The background check matches an applicant's name against law enforcement databases.
